page.title: 03BILTON WITH HARROGATE
page.content: On the map of 1897 Bilton and Harrogate are shown as entirely seperate places, with fields between the two villages. Bilton itself was recorded in the Domesday Book of William I as{Bileton,}half of it owned by a Northumbrian called Gamelbar, the other half by another Northumbrian called Archill. The River Nidd and{ {Bilton Beck}are also mentioned. In 1851 Bilton was two small communities, Batchelor Gardens and Bilton village. St. John's Church was built in 1857 as Bilton expanded, but even in 1864 the district was still known as{Bilton with Harrogate.}By 1871 Bilton was recorded as the most thinly populated part of the township of Harrogate.
